text: it's been a while since I've used
portobello mushrooms in a recipe but I
don't really know why because there's
such a great and median option to use
when you're trying to cook vegetarian
they cook up really dense and flavorful
and they're quite large so you don't
have to like go through tons of work to
get them ready in fact I just got mine
ready by removing the stem and they've
already been cleaned so I'm gonna make a
roasted caprese salad today and caprese
usually has tomato mozzarella and basil
and I'm adding an extra layer of roasted
mushrooms and the tomatoes are gonna be
roasted so arrange your portobello
mushrooms guilt side up on a baking
sheet and drizzle with a half a cup of
olive oil then drizzle with three
tablespoons of balsamic vinegar and
what's gonna happen is the mushroom
juices and the tomato juices the olive
oil and the balsamic vinegar are all
gonna cook together and make a delicious
warm vinaigrette for your salad at the
end a teaspoon of salt to have cloves of
garlic and put these in a 400-degree
oven for 20 minutes add three sliced
tomatoes and then another 20 minutes
when the mushrooms and tomatoes are done
they'll be sort of reduced in size and
concentrated in flavor which is amazing
and then you just layer it together in a
salad with mozzarella cheese basil and
some arugula so place a mushroom down on
your plate and add a couple of pieces of
fresh basil and then another mushroom
maybe one of those garlic cloves a
little bit more basil slice of
mozzarella cheese this is delicious
fresh mozzarella very delicate and
delightful a couple of slices of tomato
for a very fancy stack two slices of
tomato on top a little bit of arugula on
the side with a little basil on top you
have a beautiful elegant and delicious
vegetarian meal for dinner tonight
you
hi guys thanks for watching this video
be sure to click here if you want to
subscribe and click over here if you
